Katy decided to just shrug it off. It probably didn't mean anything. Katy got up, put on her clothes, and walked into the kitchen, where Valerie was making lunch.

"Hey, Valerie," Katy yawned. "What's for lunch?"

Valerie looked up from her cooking and said, "Oh, you're up! Good! How was your sleep?"

"It was okay," Katy replied.

"Any dreams to speak of?" Valerie asked.

Suddenly, there was a voice inside Katy's head.

"Tell her, Katy. Tell her about our little talk."

It was the voice of the human.

"No, Valerie, no dreams," Katy lied. She didn't want to worry Valerie.

The voice returned. "You didn't tell her, Katy."

Katy just ignored the voice. "So, to reiterate," Katy continued, "what's for lunch?"

"I'm making fried shrimp," Valerie replied. "They won't be ready for a while. Why don't you snack on some chips? They're in that cupboard." Valerie pointed a chubby finger towards a cupboard on the far side of the kitchen. "At least I think they're in there. I keep moving them around to hide them from Kenta." Katy giggled as she walked towards the cupboard and took a bag of sour cream and onion flavored potato chips.

"Ah, yes, my favorite," the voice said.

Katy sat down on the couch in the living room, opened the bag of chips, and started eating. She had eaten about 1/10 of the chips when Kenta came down the stairs, still in his pajamas.

"Hey, are those sour cream and onion?" Kenta asked as walked over to Katy.

Katy jerked the bag in the opposite direction of Kenta. "Valerie said these are off-limits for you."

"Hey, Valerie, can I have some chips?" he yelled into the kitchen.

"Yes, Kenta," Valerie replied.

Kenta smirked and plopped his plump rear end on the seat next to Katy. "She might hide them from me, but she doesn't forbid me from eating them." He took a handful of chips and shoved them in his mouth all at once in a series of loud slurping and chomping sounds.

"One at a time, Kenta!" Valerie nagged. Kenta muttered something through a mouthful of chips and swallowed.

Katy went to eat another chip, but she noticed something strange about the chip she had picked out.

It vaguely resembled the face of the human. Sure enough, the voice said, "So you have found me."

Katy, sick of the omnipresent human's bullcrap, quickly scarfed down the chip in one bite, thinking that she would be rid of him.

"You shouldn't have done that."

Suddenly, the roof of the house flew off, causing everyone to look up in horror. A howling wind blew through the house, chilling everyone to the bone. The wind ceased to reveal the figure of a chubby teenage boy.

It was the human.

Usually wears sweats or jeans and a tight tank top that shows you exactly which way it is to the gun show.

Zuzu uses her poison both in and out of the ring to gain any underhanded advantage she can get... and so far she's been clever enough not to get caught. She favors designer clothes and hopes to someday weasel her way onto Unova's Next Top Moemodel. Her love of expensive sweets and fine chocolates may throw a monkey wrench into those plans... especially since she's too selfish to share.

Mandy (Type: Mankey): Peppy and energetic, Mandy just loves to have fun. She has short white-blond hair, big ears, and wears her emotions on her sleeves--in the form of a big, goofy grin, as often as not. Mandy loves Hawaiian shirts, usually wearing them open over a tube top, and favors brightly-colored capris or denim cutoffs over leggings. Besides boxing, her favorite activities are bungee jumping, kicking ass in a mosh pit, and ballroom dancing. She's also got a major-league love of fruit and fruit-flavored things, and will cheerfully gorge herself if she gets the chance.

Now, some story options!

Will she be able to knock Lora and Mandy off of their high horses with a few well-placed caloric punches, or will they get wise to her wiles and turn the tables?

Our three pulchritudinous pugilist protagonists head to a sister gym overseas for a little study abroad. But they get more broadening then they bargained for when it turns out that their special training will come courtesy of, not a boxing gym, but a sumo stable! 155332221.content:
It is often said that the first step to any goal is the hardest. The part people forget to mention is that this is the case because the starting line is actually a mile of red tape and paperwork.

"I told you already, I'm Nineteen! N-I-N-E-T-E-E-N!" A loud speck of red objected, waving a small plastic card in exaggerated annoyance in the face of the skeptical clerk behind the desk. The clerk, a Chansy Moemon, raised a pink eyebrow before snatching up the card and examining it with a critical eye. The pink eyebrow managed to raise itself a little more before the woman's features smoothed out and she handed the card back, giving a pleasant smile as she smacked a heavy stamp down on a form and passed it over her desk as well.

"Sorry for the mistake, miss. You are now a fully-registered member of the Moemon Fighting League."

"Mistake shmistake." The red speck grumbled, turning and hurrying away from the desk and out of the building. It'd taken a long time just to get people to stop trying to shoo her out of the MFL's Registration Building, much less to actually believe she wasn't showing them some kind of fake license. By the time she'd actually gotten her form filled out and up to the final desk - She had no idea why there even was more than one desk if they were going to make you see all of them just to get a simple thing done - she was ready ready to burn the entire building down. As she gave the building one last annoyed look, contemplating on if she SHOULD burn it down or not, she shook her head before turning her thoughts forward.

It had taken a bit of work, but she'd gotten herself registered with the MFL and was officially allowed to participate in their competitions. She already knew who she wanted to work with as teammates, too, since it was generally accepted as a team sport and trying to go it alone would just get her laughed off even more than she already would be. A sharp-toothed grin broke out on the tan-red face, and she immediately cast her gaze along the winding path that led back to town.

"Finally, did you take a nap or something?" A leather-clad and shades-wearing squirtle moemon greeted on making eye contact with her. "Poor Meadow here is practically taking root we were waiting so long."

Next to the long white haired relic of cool-kids past, the demure looking bulbasaur moemon gave her a friendly wave and smile, chirping up. "I'm sure Aideen was just caught in a long line or something."

"Or something." Aideen echoed with a scowl, but shook her head as she motioned for her friends to begin the small trek back to town. One of the other things that made this place burn-down-to-ashes worthy was that it was built in the middle of nowhere for basically no good reason.

"We were supposed to be zoomin' out to Cobble Gym already, y'know." The Squirtle woman noted, peeking down at the much shorter girl over the top of her shades.

"Yeah well unlike you I got the third-degree from every single person in the entire building, Cascade." Aideen growled, small whisps of fire crackling briefly before dying out. She really, really would like nothing more than to just wipe that place out. It had to be some form of evil, turning a two-second process into a three hour... Whatever that even was. She was sure there was a word for it, but for the life of her she didn't know one that precisely conveyed the experience.

"She was wondering if she should go in there and give you a hand once we'd been waiting for awhile." Meadow offered placatingly, eliciting a small from her white-blue-haired friend.

"Snitching? Are you five?" Cascade complained with a shake of her head.

"Unless she was going to flood the place, I doubt it'd have helped." Aideen gave a small smirk, somewhat encouraged by the two's support. Even if Cascade was an aloof dork about it.

"Save it for cobble." Cascade shrugged.

A small, simultaneous growl from all three interrupted any further conversation.

"Perhaps we should grab lunch before we go?" Meadow suggested, eliciting another shake of her head from Cascade.

"The plans already way out of whack, so we might as well."
